title: Sheet 3B
publication_title: James Ensor: The Temptation of Saint Anthony
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section body" id="body">At bottom left, numerous creatures fly into the scene as if shot from a cannon or projected from the searchlight below (see sheet 5A). At lower right is a cannon/animal hybrid based on a foreground figure in Jacques Callot’s Temptation of Saint Anthony (see fig. 1). This sheet also includes, at left, part of the sawfish’s rostrum and the train engine from sheet 3A.

This sheet alludes to modern technology, travel, and the latest developments in aerodynamics, the hot-air balloon (which continues up into folio 2B/C) renders the setting of The Temptation contemporary. Hot-air balloons were used during the Franco-Prussian War to send communications (often by pigeon) and also helped some Parisians escape the besieged city (see fig. 2). Balloons were often reproduced in illustrated journals and posters, and their exhibitions, races, and crashes were featured frequently in the news (see fig. 3), including in stories about the latest technological advances in aviation. The hot-air balloon also served as the setting for contemporary plays, such as Jules Verne’s 1883 Kéraban-le-têtu (Keraban the Inflexible; see fig. 4).

Ensor’s deflating balloon is attached to both a traditional basket gondola and an enclosed vessel resembling a steam-powered ship or paddleboat, more commonly associated with airships and dirigibles. The rostrum of the sawfish in sheet 3A has upended the basket and the vessel so that they have disgorged their passengers. The gondola resembles those on early innovations like the Eagle (see fig. 5). Hot-air balloons also inspired fanciful designs combining engineering and imagination. These included the ship-shaped gondola of the Minerva (see fig. 6).

The British inventor Sir George Cayley, the father of fixed-wing flight, was the first to recognize that the success of the dirigible (or controllable) balloon depended on the development of an engine with a high power-to-weight ratio (see fig. 7), but his experiment with a hot-air engine and a piston engine using gunpowder failed. Albert and Gaston Tissandier designed an electric-motor-powered dirigible that they successfully launched in 1883 (see fig. 8).

Below, floating near the gondola of the hot-air balloon, is an elephant with a howdah (the seat mounted on its back). As colonial empires expanded in the nineteenth century, elephants became allied with the exotic, entertainment, and spectacle, their lumbering bodies put to work clearing jungles (see fig. 9), transporting goods (see fig. 10), and providing elevated views for touring aristocrats (see fig. 11) and visitors to zoological gardens (see fig. 12). This included Brussels’s Royal Zoological Garden founded by King Leopold II and located near the home of Ensor’s friends Ernest and Mariette Rousseau, whose salon he attended regularly. Elephants were also popular attractions at traveling circuses and for viewing at magic lantern shows (see fig. 13). The animal could also allude to the elephant owned by Phraortes, king of the Ganges, in Gustave Flaubert’s Temptation of Saint Anthony.

This sheet is technically similar to others in this row and parts of rows 4 and 5, where Ensor laid out the composition in black colored pencil and graphite before adding colored pencil sparingly to certain areas. He added greenish-blue and red colored pencil over the dark lines of the composition. The absence of media along the top edge suggests the composition was elaborated further with colored pencil after the work was joined to the mount. SMC/KJN

The action in sheets 3A, 3B, 3C, 4A, 4B, and 4C is the source of the engraving Devils Thrashing Angels and Archangels (fig. 14). It also indirectly inspired other etchings, such as The Terrible Archer (fig. 15), Cataclysms (fig. 16), Wizards in a Squall (fig. 17), and The Elephant’s Joke (fig. 18). Although Devils Thrashing Angels and Archangels is not a direct reproduction of these sheets, the chaotic composition and frightful elements are similar to Saint Anthony’s torments. Many motifs appear in both the print and the drawing, for example, the hot-air balloon, train, sawfish, headless bodies, octopi, insects, elephant, and submarine.

In the drawing the chaos is somewhat contained by the use of schematic registers, but in the etching Ensor dispensed with the organizational structure and allowed the chaos to become overwhelming. Sources of inspiration for the chaos include The Fall of the Rebel Angels by Pieter Bruegel I (fig. 19); versions of the temptation after Pieter Bruegel (fig. 20), by Martin Schongauer (fig. 21), and by Jacques Callot (fig. 22); and battle scenes by the Japanese artists Utagawa Kuniyoshi and Utagawa Kunisada (fig. 23 and fig. 24). These artists provided ideas about overlapping, clashing compositions that Ensor assimilated into his own work. He interpreted these sources to offer viewers a distilled representation that condenses the energy, imagination, anxiety, and virulence of its predecessors. Thanks to this synthesis, the image possesses its own logic and magic that captivates even as it amuses and overwhelms viewers with its detail. ST

fig. 1 Jacques Callot (French, 1592–1635). The Temptation of Saint Anthony (detail), 1635. Etching in black on ivory laid paper; image/sheet (trimmed to platemark): 35.6 × 46.6 cm (14 × 18 3/8 in.). The Art Institute of Chicago, Print and Drawing Special Account, 1938.1250. This detail shows the foreground figure that likely inspired the cannon/animal hybrid in Ensor’s drawing.

fig. 2 M. G. Mangin. Published by Grandjean et Gascard, Paris. Les ballons sortis pendant le siege de Paris, 1870–1871, 1870/80. Lithograph, partially hand-colored. Library of Congress Prints and Photographs Division, Tissandier Collection.

fig. 3 International Balloon Race from the Crystal Palace, published in Illustrated London News, 1880. Science Museum/Science & Society Picture Library, 10411186.

fig. 4 Stop (1825–1899). Keraban le têtu, par Jules Verne, 1883. Print; 35 × 24 cm (13 15/16 × 9 7/16 in.). Bibliothèque Nationale de France, Paris, Département Bibliothèque-Musée de l’Opéra. © BNF.

fig. 5 Artist unknown. Published by Ackermann & Co., London. An exact representation of the first aerial ship The Eagle, 1834. Color lithograph; 25.4 × 34.3 cm (10 × 13 1/2 in.). Science Museum/Science & Society Picture Library, 10217151.

fig. 6 The “Minerva,” published in Fulgance Marion, Wonderful Balloon Ascents or the Conquest of the Skies: A History of Balloons and Balloon Voyages (Cassell Petter & Galpin, 1870), p. 131.

fig. 7 Sir George Cayley’s design for a navigable balloon, 1837. Science Museum/Science & Society Picture Library, 10316110.

fig. 8 E. A. Tilly. Airship Powered by an Electric Motor Developed by Albert and Gaston Tissandier Departing from Auteuil, Paris, France, October 8, 1883. Wood engraving. Library of Congress Prints and Photographs Division, Tissandier Collection.

fig. 9 Artist unknown. Jardin d’acclimatation. Médiathèque de Chaumont, Collection Dutailly.

fig. 10 Benjamin Waterhouse Hawkins (English, 1807–1889). Printed by J. Graf. Published by Thomas Varty. Graphic Illustrations of Animals . . . The Elephant, 1845. Science Museum/Science & Society Picture Library, 10315205.

fig. 11 Lord and Lady Curzon on an elephant, c. 1895. Platinum print. National Media Museum/Science & Society Picture Library, 10456511.

fig. 12 Edgar Tarry Adams. Elephant at Zoological Gardens, 1898. National Media Museum/Science & Society Picture Library, 10440155.

fig. 13 Jules Chéret (French, 1836–1932). Printed by J. Chéret, Paris. Folies-Bergère, Tous les soirs les éléphants & Sir Edmunds, 1877. Bibliothèque Nationale de France, Paris. © BNF.

fig. 14 James Ensor (Belgian, 1860–1949). Devils Thrashing Angels and Archangels, 1888. Etching from a copper plate, in black with hand-coloring, on buff laid paper; image: 24.8 × 28.7 cm (9 3/4 × 11 5/16 in.); plate: 26.3 × 30.7 cm (10 3/8 × 12 1/8 in.); sheet: 33.3 × 50.8 cm (13 1/8 × 20 in.). The Art Institute of Chicago, Olivia Shaler Swan Fund Income, 1971.629.

fig. 15 James Ensor (Belgian, 1860–1949). The Terrible Archer, 1888. Etching from a zinc plate, in black, on cream wove paper; image/plate: 17.7 × 23.9 cm (7 × 9 3/8 in.); sheet: 28.3 × 39.5 cm (11 1/8 × 15 9/16 in.). The Art Institute of Chicago, Print and Drawing Club Fund, 1946.1042.

fig. 16 James Ensor (Belgian, 1860–1949). Cataclysms, 1888. Etching from a zinc plate, in black, on cream wove paper; image: 17.5 × 23.5 cm (6 7/8 × 9 1/4 in.); plate: 17.9 × 23.8 cm (7 1/16 × 9 3/8 in.); sheet: 34 × 47.2 cm (13 3/8 × 18 5/8 in.). The Art Institute of Chicago, Joseph Brooks Fair Fund, 1943.1020.

fig. 17 James Ensor (Belgian, 1860–1949). Wizards in a Squall, 1888. Etching from a zinc plate, in black, on cream wove paper; image/plate: 17.9 × 23.6 cm (7 1/16 × 9 5/16 in.); sheet: 28.6 × 39.9 cm (11 1/4 × 15 3/4 in.). The Art Institute of Chicago, Print and Drawing Club Collection, 1946.264.

fig. 18 James Ensor (Belgian, 1860–1949). The Elephant’s Joke, 1888. Etching on paper; 17.9 × 23.8 cm (7 1/16 × 9 3/8 in.). Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco, Gift of A. Justin and Lynn M. Sterling, 2005.171.4. © Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco.

fig. 19 Pieter Bruegel I (Flemish, c. 1525–1569). The Fall of the Rebel Angels, 1562. Oil on panel; 117 × 162 cm (46 × 64 in.). Royal Museums of Fine Arts of Belgium, Brussels, 584. © Royal Museums of Fine Arts of Belgium, Brussels/photograph: J. Geleyns/Ro scan.

fig. 20 Pieter van der Heyden (Flemish, c. 1530–after 1572) after Pieter Bruegel I (Flemish, c. 1525–1569). The Temptation of Saint Anthony, 1556. Engraving on laid paper; 24.3 × 32.5 cm (9 9/16 × 12 13/16 in.). The Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute, 2001.13.3. Image © Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute, Williamstown, Massachusetts, USA (photograph by Michael Agee).

fig. 21 Martin Schongauer (German, c. 1450–1491). The Temptation of Saint Anthony, 1470–75. Engraving in black on cream laid paper; sheet: 32 × 23.5 cm (12 5/16 × 9 1/16 in.). The Art Institute of Chicago, Gift of Mrs. Potter Palmer, Jr., 1955.1227.

fig. 22 Jacques Callot (French, 1592–1635). The Temptation of Saint Anthony, 1635. Etching in black on ivory laid paper; image/sheet (trimmed to platemark): 35.6 × 46.6 cm (14 × 18 3/8 in.). The Art Institute of Chicago, Print and Drawing Special Account, 1938.1250.

fig. 23 Utagawa Kuniyoshi (Japanese, 1797–1861). Published by Kogaya Katsugorō (Japanese, c. 1843–1874). The Battle of Dan-no-ura: Suke no Tsubone, Shinchūnagon Taira Tomomori, and Sagami Gorō, c. 1844. Woodblock print (nishiki-e); ink and color on paper; vertical ōban triptych; 36.7 × 75.3 cm (14 7/16 × 29 5/8 in.). Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, William Sturgis Bigelow Collection, 11.27029-31. Photograph © 2014 Museum of Fine Arts, Boston.

fig. 24 Utagawa Kunisada (Japanese, 1786–1864). Published by Kawaguchiya Uhei (Japanese, c. 1800–1852). The Killing of Ten (Jūban kiri): Soga Gorō Tokimune and Gosho no Gorōmaru Shigemune, c. 1820. Woodblock print (nishiki-e); ink and color on paper; vertical ōban; 39 × 25.5 cm (15 3/8 × 10 1/16 in.). Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, William Sturgis Bigelow Collection, 11.21579. Photograph © 2014 Museum of Fine Arts, Boston.
